thread.title: Planned Parenthood's Texas affiliate draws record crowd, $1 million from Dallas luncheon
thread.title_full: Planned Parenthood's Texas affiliate draws record crowd, $1 million from Dallas luncheon

author: Holly Haber
title: Planned Parenthood's Texas affiliate draws record crowd, $1 million from Dallas luncheon

organizations.name: mcgarr family fund of dallas women's foundation

text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
P lanned Parenthood of Greater Texas achieved something last Wednesday that no affiliate of the organization has ever done: It brought in $1 million in gross proceeds at its annual awards luncheon at the Omni Dallas Hotel. 
A record crowd of 1,600 people braved the valet-parking gridlock to get into the luncheon, which had tallied $800,000 in contributions before the doors opened. 
Co-chairs Lindsay A. Billingsley and Laura B. Wright urged the audience to give an additional $200,000 via a text-message pledge drive during the event. Methodist president to get Virginia Chandler Dykes award 
Board chair Rabbi Alan R. Freedman and invocation speaker Rev. Dr. Neil G. Cazares-Thomas both passionately expressed their dedication to health care and reproductive control for all women. 
"We face unprecedented challenges, but I'm here to tell you that the doors of Planned Parenthood in Dallas will remain open," Freedman said. Marcia Clark Coral Von Zumwalt 
The star attraction was O.J. Simpson prosecutor-turned-author Marcia Clark. 
In an on-stage interview with actress and Highland Park High School alumna Stephanie March, Clark said that she probably wouldn't be an attorney today if not for the birth control she obtained from Planned Parenthood as a teenager. 
"Unwanted kids wind up in my courtroom," she said. "I've seen the effects of what can happen when women are not allowed to control their own destiny." 
Clark's 2016 nonfiction book, Without a Doubt, details her experience with the so-called "trial of the century." 
Luncheon sponsors included: 
$20,000: Ellenore and Kirk Baker/Dallas Women's Foundation, Debbie and Gerald Barnes/Lael and Peter Brodsky, Lyda Hill, and Sue and Jay Wagley. 
$10,000: Lindsay and George Billingsley, Victoria Brown, Nancy and Clint Carlson, Laura and Walter Elcock, Amy and Lee Fikes, Al Hill Jr. in honor of Alinda Wikert, Marjorie Levy, The Lebowitz-Aberly Family Foundation, Megan McManemin, Mona Munson, Gwen and Doug Parker, Margot and Ross Perot, Deedie Rose, and Alinda Wikert/Margretta Wikert. 
$5,000: Sara and Gary Ahr, Debbie and Marc Andres/Wendy and Marc Stanley, Carol M. Barger, Flauren Bender/Amanda Shufeldt, Cecilia and Garrett Boone, Inette and Joshua Brown/Rosann and Richard Gutman, Rebecca W.
